column1: The Lubbock area is the largest contiguous cotton-growing region in the world and is heavily dependent on federal government agricultural subsidies and on irrigation water drawn from the Ogallala Aquifer. column10: with Slide Road appearing in its place.

column1: Lubbock currently does not provide intercity rail service
column2: although various proposals have been presented over the years to remedy this. One
column3: the Caprock Chief
column4: would have seen daily service as part of a Fort Worth
column5: Texas—Denver
column6: Colorado service
column7: but it failed to gain interest. Lubbock is served by the BNSF Railway company
column9: and West Texas & Lubbock Railway (WTLC). PSC interchanges with BNSF (also with UP through a UP-BNSF Haulage agreement) in Lubbock and has 19 miles of track within city limits of Lubbock with 36 customers. Options exist for transloading a variety of materials on the line
column10: from wind-turbine parts to steel shafts. PSC handles many commodities such as cottonseed
column26: and can also store cars. WTLC interchanges with BNSF (also with UP through a UP-BNSF Haulage agreement) in Lubbock. WTLC has a yard on the west side of Lubbock
column27: where they switch cars to go down their line to Levelland or to Brownfield. WTLC handles commodities of grains

column1: The city's air services are provided by Lubbock Preston Smith International Airport
column2: which is named for the Lubbock businessman who became lieutenant governor and governor of Texas. It is on the city's northeast side. The airport is the eighth-busiest airport in Texas. Lubbock Preston Smith Airport also plays host as a major hub to FedEx's feeder planes that serve cities around Lubbock.

column1: Greyhound Lines operates the Lubbock Station at 801 Broadway
column2: just east of the Lubbock County Courthouse.

column1: Public transportation is provided by Citibus
column2: a bus transit system running Monday through Saturday every week with a transit center hub in downtown. It runs bus routes throughout the city
column3: with the main routes converging at the Downtown Transfer Plaza
column4: which also houses the Greyhound bus terminal. Citibus has been in continual service since 1971
column5: when the city of Lubbock took over public transit operations. The paratransit system is called Citiaccess.

column1: Citibus' six diesel-electric hybrid buses have begun service on city routes. Managers hope the buses will use 60% of the fuel their older
column2: larger versions consume in moving customers across the city. The buses seat 23 passengers
column3: can support full-sized wheelchairs
column4: and will run on all but two city-based routes.

column1: According to the 2016 American Community Survey
column2: 80.9% of working Lubbock (city) residents commuted by driving alone
column3: 12.9% carpooled
column4: 1% used public transportation
column5: and 1.5% walked. About 1.5% used all other forms of transportation
column6: including taxi
column7: bicycle
column8: and motorcycle. About 2.3% worked at home.In 2015
column9: 7.3% of Lubbock households were without a car
column10: which decreased to 5.6% in 2016. The national average was 8.7% in 2016. Lubbock averaged 1.74 cars per household in 2016
column11: compared to a national average of 1.8 per household.

column1: In the early years of the 21st century
column2: Lubbock turned its Milwaukee Avenue into a major thoroughfare. Previously
column3: Milwaukee was a 4-mile dirt road on farm land with hardly any traffic a mile or more from major development. With growth headed westward
column4: the city allocated nearly $20 million to convert the road into a seven-lane concrete thoroughfare. In 2004
column5: the city funded the project and other developments to come by establishing a new fund that tapped part of the franchise fees received. As of 2018
column6: more than $124 million in street construction has been possible from the fund
column7: including Slide Road
column9: Indiana Avenue
column10: and the last phases of the Marsha Sharp Freeway. Public Works Director Wood Franklin said Milwaukee Avenue was conceived on the "build it and they will come" theory. Marc McDougal
column12: described the project as a well calculated risk that subsequently greatly benefited the city.

column1: United States Army officer Taylor Force after whom the Taylor Force Act was named is from Lubbock.

column2: who held the office from 1909 to 1915. State Senator William H. Bledsoe in 1923 pushed for the legislation and the first $1 million appropriation which brought Texas Tech University to Lubbock. State Representative Richard M. Chitwood
